title: Angelina Jolie discusses mom's breast cancer and her own health: 'I made choices to improve my odds'
text:
Angelina Jolie is using her own family medical history and experiences to shed light on advancements in cancer research, treatment and women's health as well as women's rights worldwide.

The Academy Award winner wrote a candid article for Time Magazine, published Thursday, in which she discussed how her late mother's battle with breast and ovarian cancer - and her own subsequent decisions to have preemptive surgeries to avoid getting the disease herself - have affected her.

The 44-year-old star also widened the topic of discussion to not only address how women's health is approached from a medical treatment standpoint, but also from a mental health, emotional well-being, and physical safety standpoint as well.

Powerful sentiments: Angelina Jolie is using her own family medical history and experiences to shed light on advancements in cancer research, treatment and women's health and rights; seen in Rome to promote Maleficent: Mistress Of Evil in early October

Angelina's mother, actress Marcheline Bertrand, died in 2007 at the age of 56 after a decade-long battle with ovarian and breast cancer.

'I remember once holding my mother’s hand, as she was receiving chemotherapy, when she started to turn purple and I had to race to get the nurse,' she wrote in the emotional essay.

'Now there are new ways to identify which chemotherapy medication is best for each patient, resulting in fewer of the horrible side effects. Fewer. It’s often still so hard on the body.'

In the written piece, the Maleficent: Mistress Of Evil actress also mentioned that her grandmother succumbed to breast cancer, and that after her mother's death she discovered that she herself carried a gene that predisposed her to the disease as well.

Memories: The actress wrote a candid article for Time Magazine, published Thursday, in which she discussed how her late mother's battle with breast and ovarian cancer affected her; seen here in 2001 with mom Marcheline

'As I stood in the hallway of the hospital waiting for my mother’s body to be collected and taken to be cremated, her doctor told me she had promised my mother that she would make sure I was informed about my medical options,' Jolie recalls in the essay.

Those options included preemptive surgeries.

'Women typically have a 13% risk of developing breast cancer over their lifetime. I had an estimated 87% risk of developing the disease and a 50% risk of ovarian cancer. Because of my high risk, experts recommended preventive surgeries,' she wrote.

To her credit, the Tomb Raider star was quite public about her surgeries, which took place in 2013 and 2015, thereby bringing further awareness to breast and ovarian cancer worldwide.

Activist: In the written piece, the Salt actress mentioned that after her mother's death she discovered that she herself carried a gene that predisposed her to cancer; seen here last week in Paris

'I had a double mastectomy and later removed my ovaries and fallopian tubes, significantly reducing, although not removing altogether, my risk of developing cancer.

'I’m often asked how my medical choices, and being public about them, have affected me,' she later wrote in the piece. 'I simply feel I made choices to improve my odds of being here to see my children grow into adults, and of meeting my grandchildren.'

The actress has six children with ex-husband Brad Pitt, including Maddox, 18, Pax, 15, Zahara, 14, Shiloh, 13, and 11-year-old twins Knox and Vivienne.

In her confessional essay, the actress was quite candid about the pain she still feels over the loss of her mother.

'She met only a few of her grandchildren and was often too sick to play with them. It’s hard now,' she wrote, '...when I think of how much their lives would have benefited from time with her and the protection of her love and grace.

'My mother fought the disease for a decade and made it into her 50s. My grandmother died in her 40s. I’m hoping my choices allow me to live a bit longer.

'I need to get regular health checkups. I see and feel changes in my body, but I don’t mind,' Jolie continued. 'I’m alive, and for now I am managing all the different issues- I inherited-. I feel more connected to other women, and I often have deeply personal conversations with strangers about health and family.'

Back in the day: In her confessional essay, Jolie was candid about the pain she still feels over the loss of her mother; seen here in a file photo with Jolie's godmother, actress Jacqueline Bisset (right) in 2001

It is at this point in the article where Angelina addresses wider issues affecting women on a global scale, beyond medical care in relation to cancer treatment.

'I have learned that when it comes to women’s health, medical advances are only one part of the picture. Mental and emotional health, and physical safety, are just as important,' she wrote.

'Without that there may be a false sense that a woman is being cared for, when in fact she is falling apart because of other pressures in her life that receive no attention at all. I understand now that we often focus on the specific cancer or illness affecting a particular woman, but miss the bigger diagnosis: her family situation, her safety and whether she is carrying stress that is undermining her health.

'All medical discoveries that extend our lives are welcome. But the bodies we are hoping to heal also need to be respected and spared preventable harm,' the actress and humanitarian concluded. 'Only if we feel safe and cared for are any of us able to reach our full potential.'
description: Angelina Jolie is using her own family medical history and experiences to shed light on advancements in cancer research, treatment and women's health and rights worldwide.
